5.2 Riemann and Beltrami and rigorous non-Euclidean geometry

Riemann’s “Über die Hypothesen …”
(given as a lecture in 1854, published posthumously in 1868) and
Beltrami’s “Saggio di interpretazione”
(1868) gave different but equivalent accounts of 2-dimensional
non-Euclidean geometry. Beltrami employed differential geometry to
justify the hyperbolic geometry of Lobachevskii-Bolyai. By studying
the pseudosphere and how it can be mapped onto the plane (in such a
way that its geodesics went to straight lines), Beltrami realized that
the unit disk can be viewed as an ‘infinite plane’. It had
been impossible to find a surface in \(\mathbb{R}^3\) that behaved
like the hyperbolic plane (the closest, but partial, being the
pseudosphere); now it was possible to realize non-Euclidean geometry
as the geometry of the interior of a disk with a novel metric. The
disk is the whole ‘plane’, its circumference a line at
infinity, line segments in the disk are ‘lines’, and one
can define a distance function
\(d(P,Q)\) that makes sense and validates Lobachevskii’s
results. From the logical point of view, this was an enormous step
forward, as the consistency of non-Euclidean geometry was now
proven.

Riemann’s account, which was stated in \(n\) dimensions, agrees
with the one that Poincaré was to use in many short
publications in 1880 and 1881 but only describe explicitly in his
major paper (Poincaré 1882). In this so-called
conformal model, the plane is again a disk, geodesics are
arcs of circles perpendicular to the boundary of the disk and angles
are true (Euclidean). The Riemann and Beltrami disks swiftly persuaded
mathematicians that the non-Euclidean geometry of Bolyai and
Lobachevskii did, after all, make rigorous mathematical sense.
Poincaré’s contribution a decade later was to make
non-Euclidean geometry the natural geometry for certain topics
elsewhere in mathematics, chiefly the developing and important subject
of Riemann surfaces.

The importance of a rigorous account of any part of mathematics should
not be ignored, but the acceptance of non-Euclidean and Riemannian
geometries went beyond the presentation of a consistent formalism. It
marks the acceptance of the abstract view that geometry is whatever
can be described in the Riemannian formalism: one has a very general
framework, allowing for a dizzying number of concrete specifications.
Thus the door was opened to the view that there are many geometries,
each of which must be consistent, and none of which need to refer to
Euclidean space, however intuitive this may be. (A parallel
development with similar outcome happened in the context of projective
geometry with Klein's work.) The number of dimensions of the
‘space’ under discussion, and the precise metric can be
modified at will (in due course, the topological character of that
‘space’ would be treated similarly). There is a
2-dimensional geometry of such-and-such a kind because a suitable
metric can be found; because there is, as it were, a map of it, not
because a surface has been found in \(\mathbb{R}^3\) with the right
properties. Indeed, it was later shown (Hilbert 1901) that there is no
surface in \(\mathbb{R}^3\) corresponding precisely to non-Euclidean
2-dimensional space.

Riemann was clear that the epistemological implications of this way of
doing geometry were immense. His lecture was a happy combination of
mathematics, philosophy and physics (Ferreirós 2006). Mathematicians
should no longer need to abstract some fundamental intuitions from
what they believe about physical space, such as the nature and
properties of straight lines or circles, and seek to build a true
geometry on the basis of some axiomatic expression of those
intuitions. Rather, the direction of thought should go in the opposite
direction: mathematicians were free to consider infinitely many
geometries. Riemann speculated about the validity of the hypotheses of
geometry "in the infinitely small" being possibly bound up with the
physical forces. Scientists could now freely investigate which
geometry is best for the mathematical explanation of empirical facts.
He envisioned the abandonment of the Newtonian conception of
phenomena, "by making in this conception the successive changes
required by facts which it cannot explain." His purely conceptual
(mathematical) research would be useful "in preventing this work from
being hampered by too narrow views, and progress in knowledge of the
interdependence of things from being checked by traditional
prejudices." In this connection, it was soon shown that it is possible
to do theoretical mechanics in the setting of non-Euclidean
geometry.
